response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the presence of a person sitting at a desk, with the robot's end-effector positioned near their neck. The robot is equipped with a gripper, which will be used to grasp and massage the person's neck. The environment includes a desk, a monitor, and other objects. The task involves applying controlled pressure and movement to the neck to provide a massage.
The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The wrist frame is aligned such that the X-axis points roughly towards the right of the person (relative to the person), the Y-axis points roughly upwards from the person's shoulder, and the Z-axis points roughly towards the back of the person's head (away from the robot).
The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion into and out of the back of the person's head. Positive Z motion moves the gripper and object further away from the robot and more into the person's head, while negative Z motion moves the gripper and object towards the robot and further away from the person's head.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move with small oscillations to apply pressure to the neck.
The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion to the person's left and right. Positive X motion moves the gripper and object to the person's right, while negative X motion moves the gripper and object to the person's left.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the object must move from side to side to massage the neck.
The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to motion up and down. Positive Y motion moves the gripper and object upwards, while negative Y motion moves the gripper and object downwards.
Based off knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the object must move upwards and downwards to massage the neck.
To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved with a combination of small oscillations along the Z-axis to apply pressure, side-to-side motion along the X-axis, and up-and-down motion along the Y-axis. The gripping force must be maintained to hold the neck securely.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert positive force along the X-axis with magnitude 0.5 N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert negative force along the Y-axis with magnitude 0.3 N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task, the robot must exert linear positive force along the Z-axis with magnitude 1.0 N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert angular clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0.1 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0.1 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert angular no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0.0 N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force:  The neck is assumed to be soft tissue over bone. A gentle grasp is needed to avoid injury, while still holding the neck securely. Considering the need for both security and gentleness, the grasp force should be between 5 and 10 N .

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "The object is a human neck, composed of soft tissue and bone. The mass of the grasped portion is estimated to be around 1 kg. The friction coefficient between the gripper and the skin is assumed to be medium (around 0.5) due to the presence of natural oils."
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "The robot will grasp the neck and then oscillate along the X, Y, and Z axes to provide a massage. The X-axis motion will be a side-to-side massage, the Y-axis motion will be an up-and-down massage, and the Z-axis motion will be a pressing and releasing massage."
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [0.1, -0.1, 0.05]
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [0.5, -0.3, 1.0, 0.1, -0.1, 0.0]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 7.5
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 10.0
```

[end of motion plan]

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
